description: In Spain's La Rioja, the regional health minister  the central government’s representative in La Rioja said the situation called for officers from the national police force and the Guardia Civil to be deployed to “guarantee the correct observance of home isolation”.
Spain (Haro) is enforcing to lock down entire blocks of a neighbourhood in Haro starting march 7

On March 9 2020, the Interterritorial Council of the National Health System announce that for areas where there is significant community transmission, it is recommended that all older people who suffer from chronic, multiple pathological diseases or with congenital or acquired immunosuppression states that limit the exits from their home or residence.

At the moment, only the Community of Madrid, the city of Vitoria and the town of Labastida are in this situation.
March 11, 2020. La Rioja recommended homeoffice for the jobs that have the possibility. Does who do not have the option, the regional government recommended flexible schedules and escalonated shifts.

On March 11, 2020, the regional government of Murcia recommended any person with symptoms of acute respiratory infection, cough, fever or low-grade fever should stay at home and call 1-1-2. In addition, the regional government has enabled the telephone number 900121212 to answer questions.

Government of Castilla and Leon published the list of preventive measures of a coercive nature for the entire population and the territory of the Community of Castilla y León on March 11. Among others, these include restriction of access of companions and visitors to public and private health centers. These are restricted to the minimum necessary to guarantee the right of minimum accompaniment of the patient who requires it, except in individual circumstances in which additional measures of care and socialisation are applied. Visits of minors to health centers are prohibited.
March 12, 2020. La Rioja (Spain) announces that people with COVID-19 should remain in lockdown and take the medical prescriptions given by the adequate entity.

Government of Castilla and Leon published the list of preventive measures of a coercive nature for the entire population and the territory of the Community of Castilla y León on March 11. Among others, these include restriction of access of companions and visitors to public and private health centers. These are restricted to the minimum necessary to guarantee the right of minimum accompaniment of the patient who requires it, except in individual circumstances in which additional measures of care and socialisation are applied. Visits of minors to health centers are prohibited.

This policy ended on March 14, with the national state of alarm. UPDATE: The original policy was supposed to end on March 26, but it ended on March 14 when Royal Decree 463/2020 that declared the state of alarm on the whole territory of Spain was singed and published.

March 12, 2020. People with covid 19 should remain in lockdown and taking the medical prescriptions given by the adequate entity, according to La Rioja's government. UPDATE: The policy's end date has been found - May 9th, 2021.
Due to the implementation of the Plan territorial de Protección civil de la región de Murcia, people are only allowed to go out only if it is for work or health reasons.

The Regional Government in Catalonia (Spain) ordered a lockdown on the towns of Igualada, Vilanova of the Camí, Santa Margarida and Òdena starting from March 13 2020. Disobeying the confinement can lead to fines up to 60,000 euros according to the Civil Protection Act.

The Spanish Ministry of Health agrees to lift the internal border restrictions in the region of Barcelona (Igualada , Vilanova del Camí, Santa Margarida de Montbui and Òdena) on April 5 because meanwhile, concerning the spread of the virus the neighbouring regions are in the same situation as the restricted areas

The Regional Government in Catalonia ordered a lockdown on the towns of Igualada, Vilanova of the Camí, Santa Margarida and Òdena starting from March 13 2020. Disobeying the confinement can lead to fines up to 60,000 euros according to the Civil Protection Act. UPDATE: has an end date

Started 13 February 2020, due to the implementation of the Plan territorial de Protección civil de la región de Murcia, people are only allowed to go out only if it is for work or health reasons. End date: 15 April, 2021 UPDATE: End date: 15 April, 2021

Government of Castilla and Leon published an order on March 13 where the visits to residential centers for public and private senior citizens are suspended, except in individual circumstances in which additional care and humanization measures are applied, to be adopted by the center's management. Moreover, users are forbidden to leave their residence.

On March 14, 2020, Spain announced a nationwide state of alarm. During the validity of the state of alarm, people will only be able to leaver their homes to purchase food, pharmaceutical products, and basic necessities; to assist health centers, services, and establishment; to travel to the workplace; to return to the place of habitual residence; to assist and care for the elderly, minors, dependents, people with disabilities, or especially vulnerable people; to travel to financial and insurance institutions; out of force majeure or situation of necessity; or any other activity of a similar nature. Per royal decree, this policy is set to last for 15 calendar days until March 29, 2020.

Government of Castilla and Leon published an order on March 13 where the visits to residential centers for public and private senior citizens are suspended, except in individual circumstances in which additional care and humanization measures are applied, to be adopted by the center's management. Moreover, users are forbidden to leave their residence. 

The original policy was supposed to end on March 27, but it actually ended on March 14 with the Royal Decree 463/2020 that declared the national state of alarm for the management of the health crisis situation caused by COVID-19. UPDATE: The original policy was supposed to end on March 27, but it actually ended on March 14 with the Royal Decree 463/2020 that declared the national state of alarm for the management of the health crisis situation caused by COVID-19.

On March 9 2020, the Interterritorial Council of the National Health System announce that for areas where there is significant community transmission, it is recommended that all older people who suffer from chronic, multiple pathological diseases or with congenital or acquired immunosuppression states that limit the exits from their home or residence.

At the moment, only the Community of Madrid, the city of Vitoria and the town of Labastida are in this situation. UPDATE: On March 14, 2020, Spain announced a nationwide lockdown.

From March 14, the national government of Spain has put in place a curfew affecting the entirety of the country, the region of Aragon included. The population of Aragon will therefore only be able to circulate on the roads or spaces of public use to carry out the following activities, which must be carried out individually, unless accompanied by people with disabilities, minors, elderly, or by other justified reason:

a) Acquisition of food, pharmaceutical and basic necessities, as well as acquisition of other products and provision of services in accordance with the provisions of article 10.
b) Assistance to health centers, services and establishments.
c) Displacement to the workplace to carry out their work, professional or business service.
d) Return to the place of habitual residence.
e) Assistance and care for the elderly, minors, dependents, people with disabilities or especially vulnerable people.
f) Travel to financial and insurance entities.
g) Due to force majeure or situation of need.
h) Any other activity of a similar nature

On March 17, 2020 in Catalonia, President of the Generalitat Quim Torra has announced the confinement of all Catalonia in a line of hardening of the measures to try to contain the contagion of coronavirus.
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory (Unspecified/Implied)

description: On March 14, 2020, Spain announced a nationwide state of alarm. During the validity of the state of alarm, people will only be able to leaver their homes to purchase food, pharmaceutical products, and basic necessities; to assist health centers, services, and establishment; to travel to the workplace; to return to the place of habitual residence; to assist and care for the elderly, minors, dependents, people with disabilities, or especially vulnerable people; to travel to financial and insurance institutions; out of force majeure or situation of necessity; or any other activity of a similar nature. Per royal decree, this policy is set to last for 15 calendar days until March 29, 2020. UPDATE: The state of alarm was set to end on March 29, 2020. On March 25, 2020, it was announced that it would be extended until April 12, 2020 and will be subject to the same conditions established previously.

description: On March 28, 2020, the Government of Spain announced that starting March 30, 2020, "stricter lockdown measures [will be enforced that require] ...  all non-essential workers to stay at home for the next two weeks," so until April 12, 2020. description: The Spanish Ministry of Health agrees to lift the internal border restrictions in the region of Barcelona (Igualada , Vilanova del Camí, Santa Margarida de Montbui and Òdena) on April 5 because meanwhile, concerning the spread of the virus the neighbouring regions are in the same situation as the restricted areas UPDATE: The internal border restrictions have been lifted because now the whole country is under similar conditions

On March 28, 2020, the Government of Spain announced that starting March 30, 2020, "stricter lockdown measures [will be enforced that require] ...  all non-essential workers to stay at home for the next two weeks," so until April 12, 2020. All other restrictions from the original lockdown procedure are still in effect, meaning that people will only be able to leaver their homes to purchase food, pharmaceutical products, and basic necessities; to assist health centers, services, and establishment; to travel to the workplace; to return to the place of habitual residence; to assist and care for the elderly, minors, dependents, people with disabilities, or especially vulnerable people; to travel to financial and insurance institutions; out of force majeure or situation of necessity; or any other activity of a similar nature. UPDATE: On April 9, 2020, it was announced that the state of alarm would be extended until April 26, 2020 with all the lockdown measures still in place.

On April 13, 2020, the stricter lockdown measures regarding nonessential labor that were added to the original lockdown policy are lifted. Starting April 13, 2020, the original lockdown measures are again in place, meaning that people will only be able to leaver their homes to purchase food, pharmaceutical products, and basic necessities; to assist health centers, services, and establishment; to travel to the workplace; to return to the place of habitual residence; to assist and care for the elderly, minors, dependents, people with disabilities, or especially vulnerable people; to travel to financial and insurance institutions; out of force majeure or situation of necessity; or any other activity of a similar nature. This is set to last until April 26, 2020, as the previous extension of the state of alarm decreed.

On March 28, 2020, the Government of Spain announced that starting March 30, 2020, "stricter lockdown measures [will be enforced that require] ...  all non-essential workers to stay at home for the next two weeks," so until April 12, 2020. All other restrictions from the original lockdown procedure are still in effect, meaning that people will only be able to leaver their homes to purchase food, pharmaceutical products, and basic necessities; to assist health centers, services, and establishment; to travel to the workplace; to return to the place of habitual residence; to assist and care for the elderly, minors, dependents, people with disabilities, or especially vulnerable people; to travel to financial and insurance institutions; out of force majeure or situation of necessity; or any other activity of a similar nature. UPDATE: On April 13, 2020, the stricter lockdown measures regarding nonessential labor that were added to the original lockdown policy are lifted. Starting April 13, 2020, the original lockdown measures are again in place, set to last until April 26, 2020, as the previous extension of the state of alarm decreed.

Starting April 26, 2020, there are exceptions to the lockdown. Persons under 14 years of age and a responsible adult may now stay outside their home during specific times. All other people will only be able to leave their homes to purchase food, pharmaceutical products, and basic necessities; to assist health centers, services, and establishment; to travel to the workplace; to return to the place of habitual residence; to assist and care for the elderly, minors, dependents, people with disabilities, or especially vulnerable people; to travel to financial and insurance institutions; out of force majeure or situation of necessity; or any other activity of a similar nature.This policy is is in effect during the validity of the state of alarm until May 10, 2020.

On April 21,  Spain's Health Minister Salvador Illa announced that, beginning April 26, restrictions regarding outside activity for children 14 years old or younger (imposed under the March 14 lockdown) will be lifted on April 26. Under these lifted restrictions, children are allowed "outside for one hour a day with a parent and must remain within a kilometer, or around 0.6 miles, of their homes." All other restrictions imposed by the March 14 lockdown are still in place.

On March 14, the National Government of Spain announces that, starting March 15, the entire population of the country (around 47 million) will be confined to a lockdown to curb the spread of Covid-19.  Under this lockdown, "citizens can leave their homes ONLY to buy groceries and pharmaceutical products, go to the bank or hospital, ... to take care of dependents/elderly," or walk the dog. Additionally, while "on the street, they must be unaccompanied at all times, and while they can go to work, most workplaces are to be closed to the public until further notice." (Ex. "Bars, restaurants, and shops selling anything but food and other staples must shut down. All leisure and sports activities also have to close, including cinemas, theaters, swimming pools or football grounds.") This lockdown is set to be in place as long as the National State of Alarm is still active.
 UPDATE: From April 26, 2020, exceptions to the lockdown are extended. Persons under 14 years of age (children) and a responsible adult may now stay outside their home during the state of alarm at specific times. Details can be found in the source document.
compliance: Mandatory (Unspecified/Implied),Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: On April 13, 2020, the stricter lockdown measures regarding nonessential labor that were added to the original lockdown policy are lifted. Starting April 13, 2020, the original lockdown measures are again in place, meaning that people will only be able to leaver their homes to purchase food, pharmaceutical products, and basic necessities; to assist health centers, services, and establishment; to travel to the workplace; to return to the place of habitual residence; to assist and care for the elderly, minors, dependents, people with disabilities, or especially vulnerable people; to travel to financial and insurance institutions; out of force majeure or situation of necessity; or any other activity of a similar nature. This is set to last until April 26, 2020, as the previous extension of the state of alarm decreed. UPDATE: The state of alarm was previously updated to last until April 26, 2020. On April 24, 2020, it was announced that it would be extended until May 10, 2020 and will be subject to the same conditions established previously.

On April 13, 2020, the stricter lockdown measures regarding nonessential labor that were added to the original lockdown policy are lifted. Starting April 13, 2020, the original lockdown measures are again in place, meaning that people will only be able to leaver their homes to purchase food, pharmaceutical products, and basic necessities; to assist health centers, services, and establishment; to travel to the workplace; to return to the place of habitual residence; to assist and care for the elderly, minors, dependents, people with disabilities, or especially vulnerable people; to travel to financial and insurance institutions; out of force majeure or situation of necessity; or any other activity of a similar nature. This is set to last until April 26, 2020, as the previous extension of the state of alarm decreed. UPDATE: Starting April 26, 2020, there are exceptions to the lockdown. Persons under 14 years of age and a responsible adult may now stay outside their home during specific times. This policy is is in effect during the validity of the state of alarm.

From May 1, 2020, exceptions to the lockdown are extended in that "the performance of non-professional activities of care and harvesting of agricultural productions" is now allowed. Details can be found in the source document. This policy is in effect until May 4, 2020, when Spain will enter a gradual, asymmetric de-escalation period.

From May 2, 2020, exceptions to the lockdown are extended. Persons 14 years of age and older may now engage in non-professional physical activity in the open air during the state of alarm at specific times. Details can be found in the source document. This policy is in effect until May 4, 2020, when Spain will enter a gradual, asymmetric de-escalation period.

This lockdown is set to be in place as long as the National State of Alarm is still active.

description: Starting April 26, 2020, there are exceptions to the lockdown. Persons under 14 years of age and a responsible adult may now stay outside their home during specific times. All other people will only be able to leave their homes to purchase food, pharmaceutical products, and basic necessities; to assist health centers, services, and establishment; to travel to the workplace; to return to the place of habitual residence; to assist and care for the elderly, minors, dependents, people with disabilities, or especially vulnerable people; to travel to financial and insurance institutions; out of force majeure or situation of necessity; or any other activity of a similar nature.This policy is is in effect during the validity of the state of alarm until May 10, 2020. UPDATE: On April 25, 2020, Spain’s Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez announces that, starting May 2, 2020, individuals will be allowed out to exercise alone. People living together will be permitted to take short walks together. Additionally, individuals that are 70 and "vulnerable adults" who may be accompanied by a carer are allowed to leave their home for exercise. However, these activities are subject to certain time frames and social distancing measures.

From May 1, 2020, exceptions to the lockdown are extended in that "the performance of non-professional activities of care and harvesting of agricultural productions" is now allowed. Details can be found in the source document. This policy is in effect until May 4, 2020, when Spain will enter a gradual, asymmetric de-escalation period. UPDATE: From May 2, 2020, exceptions to the lockdown are extended. Persons 14 years of age and older may now engage in non-professional physical activity in the open air during the state of alarm at specific times. Details can be found in the source document.

On May 4, Leon y Castilla enters Phase 0 of Spain’s 4-phase de-escalation plan. Additionally, the lockdown exemption "regarding legitimate reasons for leaving the house-" such as "to buy food, basic or pharmaceutical items; to attend medical centres; to go to and from work; [and] to look after children, older people or those with disabilities or who are especially vulnerable-" is now included in this phase 0. Due to the asynchronous nature of the de-escalation plan, this loosened restriction will now be coded subnationally, as how long it lasts locally largely depends on how well Leon y Castilla handles its virus environment.

On May 4, Leon y Castilla entered Phase 0 of Spain’s 4-phase de-escalation plan. Additionally, the lockdown lifting allowing “Individuals that are 14 or older, under 70, and non-dependent” to "take one-hour walks, accompanied by one person, once a day within 1 km of their homes, or do sports like riding a bike alone within their city" is now included in this phase 0. Due to the asynchronous nature of the de-escalation plan, this loosened restriction on lockdown will now be coded subnationally, as how long it lasts locally largely depends on how well where the Leon y Castilla community handles its virus environment. (More info on the curfew side of this policy can be found in the "curfew" category.)

Spain on the 28th April announces that starting from May 4, as part of Phase 0 of the 4-phase de-escalation plan, athletes qualified by the Higher Sports Council as being of a high level or of national interest, may carry out training individually, outdoors, and only in the province where they reside. They may freely access, if necessary, those natural spaces in which they must carry out their sporting activities, such as the sea, rivers, or reservoirs. Additionally, trainers are allowed to accompany athletes, and an additional person may be in attendance in the case of paralympic sports. Due to the asynchronous nature of the de-escalation plan, this loosened restriction on lockdown will now be coded subnationally, as how long it lasts locally largely depends on how well where the Leon y Castilla community handles its virus environment.

On May 4,  The Leon y Castilla Community, in Spain, enters to Phase 0. Due to this transition, citizens are now allowed to leave their house to go to visit businesses as long as the business meets a set of specific requirements and the citizen already has an appointment scheduled at said business.

As of May 4, 2020, Madrid enters Phase 0 of Spain’s 4-phase de-escalation plan. The lockdown exemption regarding legitimate reasons for leaving the house, such as to buy food, basic or pharmaceutical items; to attend medical centers; to go to and from work; and to look after children, older people, or those with disabilities or who are especially vulnerable is now included in this phase 0.

As of May 4, 2020, Madrid enters Phase 0 of Spain’s 4-phase de-escalation plan. Athletes who are designated as high-performance by the Superior Council for Sports may train individually in the open air in their province of residence. If necessary, they may access natural areas required for their activity, such as the sea, rivers, or reservoirs. There is no limit on training times, and trainers are allowed to accompany athletes; an additional person may be in attendance in the case of paralympic sports.

On May 4, Andalusia entered Phase 0 of Spain’s 4-phase de escalation plan. Additionally, the lockdown lifting allowing “Individuals 14 or older, under 70, and non-dependent” to "take one-hour walks, accompanied by one person, once a day within half a mile of their homes, or do sports like riding a bike alone within their city" is now included in this phase 0. Due to the asynchronous nature of the de escalation plan, this loosened restriction on lockdown will now be coded subnationally, as how long it lasts locally largely depends on how well Andalusia handles its virus environment. (More info on the curfew side of this policy can be found in the "curfew" category.)

On May 4, Andalusia enters Phase 0 of Spain’s 4-phase de escalation plan. Additionally, the lockdown exemption "regarding legitimate reasons for leaving the house-" such as "to buy food, basic or pharmaceutical items; to attend medical centres; to go to and from work; [and] to look after children, older people or those with disabilities or who are especially vulnerable-" is now included in this phase 0. Due to the asynchronous nature of the de escalation plan, this loosened restriction will now be coded subnationally, as how long it lasts locally largely depends on how well Andalusia handles its virus environment.

On May 4, Andalucia transitions to Phase 0. Due to this transition, citizens are now allowed to leave their house to go to visit businesses as long as the business meets a set of specific requirements and the citizen already has an appointment scheduled at said business.

Spain on May 3 announces that starting from May 4, as part of Phase 0 of the 4-phase de-escalation plan, athletes qualified by the Higher Sports Council as being of a high level or of national interest, may carry out training individually, outdoors, and only in the province where they reside. They may freely access, if necessary, those natural spaces in which they must carry out their sporting activities, such as the sea, rivers, or reservoirs. Additionally, trainers are allowed to accompany athletes, and an additional person may be in attendance in the case of paralympic sports.

*As the 4-phase deescalation plan is asynchronous for each national region, whenever Andalusia enters a phase, it's effects will be coded sub- nationally.

On May 4, with Andalucia's transition into Phase 0 of Spains deescalation plan, "Athletes who are designated as “high-performance” by the Superior Council for Sports may train individually in the open air in their province of residence. Spain on the 28th April announces that starting from May 4, as part of Phase 0 of the 4-phase de-escalation plan, athletes qualified by the Higher Sports Council as being of a high level or of national interest, may carry out training individually, outdoors, and only in the province where they reside. They may freely access, if necessary, those natural spaces in which they must carry out their sporting activities, such as the sea, rivers, or reservoirs. Additionally, trainers are allowed to accompany athletes, and an additional person may be in attendance in the case of paralympic sports. Due to the asynchronous nature of the de-escalation plan, this loosened restriction on lockdown will now be coded subnationally, as how long it lasts locally largely depends on how well where the Leon y Castilla community handles its virus environment. UPDATE: The original "Phase 0" of Spain's 4-phase de-escalation plan was set to last until May 11. It had been extended to May 25.

On May 4,  The Leon y Castilla Community, in Spain, enters to Phase 0. Due to this transition, citizens are now allowed to leave their house to go to visit businesses as long as the business meets a set of specific requirements and the citizen already has an appointment scheduled at said business.

As of May 4, 2020, Catalonia enters Phase 0 of Spain’s 4-phase de-escalation plan. The lockdown exemption regarding legitimate reasons for leaving the house, such as to buy food, basic or pharmaceutical items; to attend medical centers; to go to and from work; and to look after children, older people, or those with disabilities or who are especially vulnerable is now included in this phase 0. UPDATE: On May 11, 2020, Terres del l'Ebre, Camp de Tarragona and Pirineu-Aran move into Phase 1 of Spain’s 4-phase de-escalation plan. The Catalan government proposed dividing Catalonia into health regions and not provinces. For this reason, 90% of people will stay in Phase 0, including the region of Barcelona, Central Catalonia, Girona, and Lleida, according to the Minister of Health.

On May 18, 2020, Valencia entered Phase 0 of Spain’s 4-phase de-escalation plan. The lockdown lifting allowing “Individuals 14 or older, under 70, and non-dependent” to "take one-hour walks, accompanied by one person, once a day within half a mile of their homes, or do sports like riding a bike alone within their city" is now included in this phase 0. UPDATE: On May 18, 2020, Valencia, Spain moves into Phase 1. Residents are always allowed to move within the limits of the province in which they reside. All citizens - except those who are in quarantine or have coronavirus symptoms- can go for a walk once a day at a maximum distance of one kilometer from home.

As of May 4, 2020, Madrid enters Phase 0 of Spain’s 4-phase de-escalation plan. The lockdown exemption regarding legitimate reasons for leaving the house, such as to buy food, basic or pharmaceutical items; to attend medical centers; to go to and from work; and to look after children, older people, or those with disabilities or who are especially vulnerable is now included in this phase 0. UPDATE: On May 25, 2020 Madrid, Spain moves into Phase 1. As of May 25, it is now possible to go out without legitimate reasons. Spain has a timetable in place determining when different groups can take their exercise outside.

Two weeks after the start of the de-escalation, Barcelona have obtained the green light to engage in the process. The Government has approved its pass to phase 1 next Monday ( May 25) along with the other great laggard, the community of Castilla y León. 
-All businesses can be opened with 30% of the capacity and as long as the premises do not exceed 400 square meters in area. 
-Meetings with family and friends may be held, as long as the groups do not exceed 10 people and taking into account the distance and hygiene measures. You can also go to the terraces, which will have to have a distance of two meters between tables, whose number may not exceed 50% compared to the previous year.

-Hotels and tourist accommodation may be opened, but common areas may not be used. 
-Libraries will be opened for lending and reading, with capacity reduced to 30%, as will museums. 
-The theater, cinema and concerts can be reactivated with a third of the capacity and less than 20 people indoors and less than 200 outdoors.

On May 25th, Madrid entered phase 1 of reduced restrictions from the national lockdown. "The rules now allow for meetings of as many as 10 people, for smaller shops to open without prior appointment as well as restricted access to funerals, religious services and gyms."
compliance: Mandatory (Other; please list other enforcement mechanisms in the text entry)

description: On May 18, 2020, Valencia, Spain moves into Phase 1. Residents are always allowed to move within the limits of the province in which they reside. All citizens - except those who are in quarantine or have coronavirus symptoms- can go for a walk once a day at a maximum distance of one kilometer from home. UPDATE: On June 1, 2020, Valencia enters Phase 2. The restriction that limited the distance to walk to one kilometer outside the municipality of residence ends.
On June 1, 2020, the Valencian Community transitions to Phase 2. The time slots for walking and playing sports will be eliminated, as well as for going out for children and the elderly.

In the framework of the de-escalation plan that is being carried out in Spain to try to achieve the "new normal", Barcelona will enter phase 2 as of next Monday, June 8. 
In phase 2, meetings of up to 15 people can be held. In addition, in phase 2 all the previously established time slots are eliminated, with the exception of the slot reserved for people over 70 years of age, which will be between 10:00 and 12:00 and between 19:00 and 19:00. 20:00 hour

Catalonia, June 6, 2020, fourteen weeks after the closure of educational centers that preceded the confinement and after almost six weeks of dancing phases and what can and cannot be done in each one, all of Catalonia today is in phase 3, the last before recovering the normality (with conditions).

The Ministry of Health yesterday gave the green light to the change of phase in Barcelona and the metropolitan area and Lleida. The Official State Gazette (BOE) must publish today the order for this phase change, which means that all of Catalonia becomes a single territorial unit, which means that mobility restrictions between the different health regions have ended.

UPDATE: As of June 21, 2020, the state of alarm and phase system ended in Spain. The community of Madrid, instead of the central government, will maintain different restrictions from June 21, when the region will enter the new normality.

As of June 8, 2020, Madrid is allowed to progress to phase 2 of easing the national lockdown restrictions. Timetables for outdoor exercise are lifted, while restaurants and bars are allowed to open their interiors at 40 percent capacity. Additionally, swimming pools and beaches are allowed to open under the requirements of social distancing rules and a maximum of 30 percent occupancy. UPDATE: This policy ended on June 20, 2020, since on June 21, 2020, the state of alarm ended and the entire country entered into the so-called "new normality" (Madrid skipped phase 3).

On July 2, 2020, Asturias government announces the resolution of the liberation of outdoor activities. From July 3, people will be able to do outdoor activities as long as they wear a mask and social distancing of at least 1.5 meters can be assured. Citizens should also have no symptoms or recent contact with possitive cases.

July 2nd, 2020

Asturias, España.

Asturias government announces the resolution of the liberation of outdoor activities.

From the next day and onwards, people will be able to do outdoor activities as long as they wear a mask and social distancing of at least 1.5 meters can be assured. 

Citizens should also have no symptoms or recent contact with possitive cases. UPDATE: End Date: on Oct 15,2020 Asturias returned to Phase 2 lockdown - restriction of hotels and recomendation of staying at home- though not the alarm state or complete lockdown.

The Valencian Community announced that people over 6 years old can only go outside - in indoors and outdoors spaces - wearing masks as long as it’s not possible to maintain the 1.5 meters of social distance.

On July 20, 2020, The Government of Catalonia announced the expansion of regulations including a mandatory stay at home order to the counties of Sant Feliu de Llobregat (Barcelona), Figueres, and Vilafant (Girona). The restrictions will last 15 days. Residents are allowed to leave their home for essential errands, such as buying medicine.

On August 21, 2020, the Community of Madrid, Spain, advised residents to remain at home and urged people to avoid unnecessary trips and meetings without enforcing a mandatory lockdown as the number of cases increased rapidly over the previous days.

Spain: A judge has authorized a request by the regional government of Castilla y Leon to confine the 32,000 residents of Aranda de Duero, in Burgos province, due to a recent surge in cases. The lockdown will go into effect on 21 August and it will introduce measures similar to Phase 1 of the national deescalation plan that ended on 21 June. Residents will be able to come and go within the city limits, but entering and leaving Aranda will only be permitted for work or health reasons, to return to ones regular place of residence, to care for the elderly or for other reasons considered to be force measure.

On 31 August, the regional health authority in Spain, Valencia region confined the 5,800 inhabitants of the municipality of Beniganim for two weeks, given the increase in coronavirus infections after a new outbreak began in mid-August.

From 9 September, the areas of Son Gotleu, Can Capes, La Soledat Nord and part of Son Canals, located in Palma, on the Spanish island of Mallorca, will be closed off for at least 15 days, beginning at 10pm. Residents will only be allowed in and out for essential business such as work, school and visits to the doctor. Closing time for bars and restaurants is set at 10pm and all religious services, except for funerals, are being suspended. Public parks, sports arenas and gyms cannot open during the confinement period.
On September 10, 2020, it was announced by the administration of Aragon state, Spain, that the free entry and exit of people residing in the municipality of Andorra is restricted

As of September 21, 2020, the Madrid region implements a partial lockdown on the worst-hit 37 zones of the capital. The restrictions will apply to areas where there are more than 1,000 cases per 100,000 people. The residents are only allowed to leave their zone to go to work, seek medical care or take their children to school.

As of September 21, 2020, the Madrid region implements a partial lockdown on the worst-hit 37 zones of the capital. The restrictions will apply to areas where there are more than 1,000 cases per 100,000 people. The residents are only allowed to leave their zone to go to work, seek medical care or take their children to school. UPDATE: The Madrid regional government announced on September 25, 2020 that it will extend the coronavirus mobility restrictions that currently affect 37 basic health areas in the region to eight new zones.

The restrictions will apply to areas where there are more than 1,000 cases per 100,000 people. The residents are only allowed to leave their zone to go to work, seek medical care or take their children to school.

On the 6th of October of 2020 the parliament of Andalusia ordered the restriction of mobility in the municipality of Linares (province of Jaen), effective from the 6th of October and for an unspecified duration.

Extremadura, Spain's Minister of Health, José María Vergeles, announced on January 5, 2021 the "perimeter closure of the towns of Zarza la Mayor, Cabezuela del Valle, Torreorgaz, and Pueblonuevo del Guadiana" due to high infection rates. "This restriction is set to be in place for six days but may be extended."

The Government of Catalonia has imposed a municipal lockdown as of January 7 , 2021 until January 18. It has decreed the closure of all non essential activities and it will not be possible to leave the municipalities during this period of time.

The Government of Catalonia has imposed a municipal lockdown from January 7, 2021 until January 18.This means that it will not be possible to enter or leave the municipalities,as well as the closure of all non essential activities.

On Jan. 4, 2021, health minister Alba Vergés announced that residents in Catalonia will not be allowed to leave their municipality of residence for 10 days from January 7 until January 17, including all days of the week.
January 13, 2021. Galicia (Spain) bans all non-essential travel in seven largest cities.
Galicia bans all non-essential travel in seven largest cities. UPDATE: The policy's end date has been found - October 15th, 2021.

Castilla-La Mancha starting on January 18, 2021 for at least 10 days "announced that every one of its more than 900 municipalities is being confined, and residents may only exit or enter on essential business."

The Madrid government will place the region under a perimetral lockdown between March 17, 2021 and March 21, 2021 for the Father’s Day long weekend in accordance with the agreement reached by the Inter-Territorial Council of the National Health System, which brings together health officials from the regions and the central Health Ministry.
